caption_original: The Supreme Court of Canada has ruled that there is an Aboriginal right to fish for food, social and ceremonial purposes. However, the buying, selling, trading, bartering or the offer to buy, sell, trade or barter Indigenous fishery resources harvested for food, social and ceremonial purposes is not permitted. Fishery Officers investigate any known or suspected incidents of persons engaging in illegal sale of fish and have authority under the Fisheries Act to fine or prosecute offenders.
caption_cleaned: The Supreme Court of Canada has ruled that there is an Aboriginal right to fish for food, social and ceremonial purposes. However, the buying, selling, trading, bartering or the offer to buy, sell, trade or barter Indigenous fishery resources harvested for food, social and ceremonial purposes is not permitted. Fishery Officers investigate any known or suspected incidents of persons engaging in illegal sale of fish and have authority under the Fisheries Act to fine or prosecute offenders.

caption_original: We announced a new science program to help measure the effect human activities have on marine environments. Baseline data will be collected to help us better monitor changes over time. The Coastal Environmental Baseline Program will be collecting data from 6 ports in Quebec, Newfoundland, New Brunswick, British Columbia and the Arctic. Learn more about this program here: http://ow.ly/bQcu30f7Ld2

caption_original: Our Canadian Hydrographic Service is proud to name its latest survey vessel in memory of Kalman L. Czotter who dedicated 42 years to the Service. Mr. Czotter was a talented Hydrographer-in-Charge, leading teams during hydrographic surveys in remote areas of the BC coast.  Those surveys were used to create charts which enable safe navigation in British Columbia’s waters. http://ow.ly/zv8330fmsgH

Those surveys were used to create charts which enable safe navigation in British Columbia’s waters.

caption_original:
Our scientists dove two kilometers deep to study previously unexplored underwater mountains off the coast of Vancouver Island: the Union and Dellwood Seamounts.
We used a camera to explore these two extinct volcanoes and the biodiversity hotspots they support. This research will offer insight into their ecological importance and inform how we might better conserve this potential Marine Protect Area. Take a look at what we discovered and celebrate this unique marine habitat.
http://ow.ly/mAu530f9FMi

We used a camera to elore these two extinct volcanoes and the biodiversity hotspots they support. This research will offer insight into their ecological importance and inform how we might better conserve this potential Marine Protect Area. Take a look at what we discovered and celebrate this unique marine habitat.

caption_original: The Atlantic Wolffish may look scary with its large and sharp teeth, but this species is non-aggressive towards other fish. It uses its teeth to cut through the hard shells of molluscs and crustaceans. Wolffish are quite shy, preferring to stay in small caves. http://ow.ly/PfPb30feUT9

caption_original: Today, we announced additional marine refuges that will contribute to Canada’s marine conservation targets. Located in New Brunswick and Nova Scotia, these marine refuges offer long-term protection to Atlantic salmon and groundfish, such as haddock, and brings Canada’s total of protected marine and coastal areas to 3.63%. Learn more about how we’re taking concrete steps to protect our oceans! http://ow.ly/w98B30ftsO8
caption_cleaned: Today, we announced additional marine refuges that will contribute to Canada’s marine conservation targets. Located in New Brunswick and Nova Scotia, these marine refuges offer long-term protection to Atlantic salmon and groundfish, such as haddock, and brings Canada’s total of protected marine and coastal areas to 3%. Learn more about how we’re taking concrete steps to protect our oceans! 8

caption_original: Thanks to the Oceana Canada and DFO joint expedition, our researchers discovered previously unexplored areas of the Gulf of St. Lawrence. From August 23 to 30, the scientific team sampled and collected scientific data and filmed high-definition footage of the seafloor. Essential information on marine species living in surface waters, such as seabirds, sea turtles and sharks was also collected. This unique experience helped our scientists make major progress to document the richness of the marine environment. Valuable information that will help better protect it! Learn more about the expedition here: http://ow.ly/MLka30f0y6S

caption_original: What an experience! One of our summer students, Kurtis Smith, gathered fish larval samples last week with an Aquatic Science Biologist, Jason Barnucz. This work helps us find the location of juvenile life stages of at-risk species. Once we know where they are, we can determine the activities that are most harmful to them. We are extremely grateful for the contributions of our summer students.

caption_original: Could there be dinosaurs in Canadian waters? Lake sturgeons can be traced back to the Cretaceous period, and they have evolved very slowly over the past 100 million years. For this reason, scientists refer to them as “living fossils.” However, after all this time, they are now an endangered species due to overfishing and pollution. Learn more about the threats they face and recovery efforts: http://ow.ly/dxuf30fmiBC

caption_original: Two biologists from our Aquatic Invasive Species Program addressed students from the University of Waterloo’s Collaborative Water Program. Julia Colm and Maude Tremblay discussed the threats that invasive species, like Asian carps, pose to Canadian watersheds. The students recently explored the Grand River in Ontario to identify and examine current water issues. For more information about Aquatic Invasive Species, please visit: http://ow.ly/KkIg30fbSqz

caption_original: This summer, our scientists returned to Canada’s Arctic Beaufort Sea to learn more about the diverse species that live there. With the support of Inuvialuit experts and collaborators from some of Canada’s top research universities, our researchers are sailing on the F/V Frosti to better understand the relationship between these fish and their extreme environment. During this summer and next, we will sample never before recorded areas of the Beaufort Sea with trawls and science equipment. http://ow.ly/bt9830ffcg4
caption_cleaned: This summer, our scientists returned to Canada’s Arctic Beaufort Sea to learn more about the diverse species that live there. With the support of Inuvialuit eerts and collaborators from some of Canada’s top research universities, our researchers are sailing on the F/V Frosti to better understand the relationship between these fish and their extreme environment. During this summer and next, we will sample never before recorded areas of the Beaufort Sea with trawls and science equipment.

caption_original: We’re back from crossing the Northwest Passage through Canada’s Arctic waters. Two hydrographers and a technical expert from Fisheries and Oceans Canada worked with a team from the Polar Research Institute of China to collect hydrographic data to map the seafloor. The teams also discussed potential opportunities for future scientific collaboration.
caption_cleaned: We’re back from crossing the Northwest Passage through Canada’s Arctic waters. Two hydrographers and a technical eert from Fisheries and Oceans Canada worked with a team from the Polar Research Institute of China to collect hydrographic data to map the seafloor. The teams also discussed potential opportunities for future scientific collaboration.

caption_original: The Marine Institute is the first to receive close to $4.7 million to restore eelgrass beds and marine life habitat through the development of artificial reefs. This will help restore migratory corridors for Atlantic salmon and increase ecosystem productivity to support Species At Risk such as the Blue whale and Leatherback sea turtles. This project will benefit this entire ecosystem in Placentia Bay, Newfoundland and Labrador. Congratulations to the Marine Institute! We look forward to our partnership and the good work that lies ahead.  The $75 Million Coastal Restoration Fund, part of Canada’s Oceans Protection Plan, supports projects that help to restore coastal aquatic habitats. http://ow.ly/jOz130f4b8R
caption_cleaned: The Marine Institute is the first to receive close to $4.7 million to restore eelgrass beds and marine life habitat through the development of artificial reefs. This will help restore migratory corridors for Atlantic salmon and increase ecosystem productivity to support Species At Risk such as the Blue whale and Leatherback sea turtles. This project will benefit this entire ecosystem in Placentia Bay, Newfoundland and Labrador. Congratulations to the Marine Institute! We look forward to our partnership and the good work that lies ahead. The $75 Million Coastal Restoration Fund, part of Canada’s Oceans Protection Plan, supports projects that help to restore coastal aquatic habitats.

caption_original: Aquatic invasive species are among the main threats to the health of the Great Lakes. Asian carp species, including Grass Carp, are considered high risk. We take these threats very seriously, and are committed to responding quickly and effectively. In hopes of preventing additional Grass Carp spawning attempts in the Sandusky River, we’re working with the Ohio Department of Natural Resources to help capture this invasive species. We sent a crew from the Asian Carp Program with our hybrid electrofishing-netting boat and trammel nets.
caption_cleaned: Aquatic invasive species are among the main threats to the health of the Great Lakes. Asian carp species, including Grass Carp, are considered high risk. We take these threats very seriously, and are committed to responding quickly and effectively. In hopes of preventing additional Grass Carp spawning attempts in the Sandusky River, we’re working with the Ohio Department of Natural Resources to help capture this invasive species. We sent a crew from the Asian Carp Program with our hybrid electrofishing-netting boat and trammel nets.

caption_original: Greenland sharks are the only sharks that can tolerate the cold Arctic waters. Most Greenland sharks have a parasite, Ommatokoita elongate, that attaches to their eyes, destroys the tissues, and causes partial to complete blindness. The Greenland shark lives in deep water where there is rarely light, so they mainly use their other senses to get around. We have been tagging Greenland sharks as part of the Tremblay Ecosystem Approach project in Nunavut to track their movement and determine their role in the food web.
caption_cleaned: Greenland sharks are the only sharks that can tolerate the cold Arctic waters. Most Greenland sharks have a parasite, Ommatokoita elongate, that attaches to their eyes, destroys the tissues, and causes partial to complete blindness. The Greenland shark lives in deep water where there is rarely light, so they mainly use their other senses to get around. We have been tagging Greenland sharks as part of the Tremblay Ecosystem Approach project in Nunavut to track their movement and determine their role in the food web.

caption_original: Abandoned and wrecked vessels are a growing problem for coastal communities across Canada as they create significant environmental, economic and safety concerns. Today we announced $1.3 million over the next five years as part of Canada’s Oceans Protection Plan to help remove abandoned and wrecked vessels from small craft harbours. We’re working to keep harbours that are critical to the commercial fishing industry open and in good repair. More information is available at http://ow.ly/iBqp30eZk5L

caption_original:
CPAWS announced today that Canada will host the next International Marine Protected Areas Congress (IMPAC5) in Vancouver, British Columbia. The Congress will take place in 2021 and will continue the international ‎dialogue on how to protect our marine ecosystems. http://ow.ly/BTpV30f1hLq 
Marine Protected Areas help provide long term protection by managing activities in ways that help conserve healthy marine ecosystems. They protect living creatures and the habitats they call home.

The Congress will take place in and will continue the international ‎dialogue on how to protect our marine ecosystems. Marine Protected Areas help provide long term protection by managing activities in ways that help conserve healthy marine ecosystems. They protect living creatures and the habitats they call home.

caption_original:
It’s that time of year again! 
We’re in the southern Gulf of St. Lawrence counting fish aboard the Canadian Coast Guard ship Teleost. Every year since 1971, our scientists return to collect fish population and oceanographic data. This survey helps determine responsible fishing quotas and is one of Canada’s longest unbroken marine ecosystems studies.  
Learn more about how we carry out this research: http://ow.ly/jJUW30fpeXe

caption_original: Every morning, the ecosystem research team members, in Tremblay Sound, Nunavut, are assigned different research projects. These include Greenland shark research, narwhal tagging and Arctic char tagging. Most of the work is done in a dry suit near the shore, on boats or in the wet lab. What an amazing opportunity to participate in this incredible research program.

What an amazing opportunity to participate in this incredible research program.

caption_original: Our ecosystem research team in Tremblay Sound, Nunavut, consists of 17 members that all share a 24-hour polar bear and net watch.  The nets are used to capture Arctic char, Arctic cod and narwhals for research, and polar bears are a reality.

caption_original: Humpback whales are the pop music sensation of the ocean! During mating season, these creatures sing complex ballads. These songs are 10 to 20 minutes long, and the whales repeat the same song for several hours. Impressively, they compose new songs every year! http://ow.ly/y7IX30fpd0i

caption_original:
You can help us protect Leatherback Sea Turtles! This endangered species spends the summer and fall the southern Gulf of St. Lawrence and the Northumberland Strait.  To report a sighting, contact the Canadian Sea Turtle Network : 1-888-729-4667 or info@seaturtle.ca.
If you need help releasing an entangled Leatherback Sea Turtle, contact fishery officers at our nearest office: http://ow.ly/9s7F30fwqhI ‎. For tips on handling and releasing Leatherback Sea Turtles:  http://ow.ly/ljWp30fwqiA 
Fishermen, don’t forget to record any incidents involving Leatherback Sea Turtles in your Species at Risk logbook and return it to us.

caption_original:
During the Tremblay Ecosystem Approach research season in Nunavut, we’ve been lucky enough to spot bowhead whales. Bowheads can weigh between 75 to 100 tons, reach a length of 18 m, and live up to 100 years; yet, can still manage to launch their massive bodies out of the water! Wow! 

Bowheads filter water through baleen by straining the surface of the water to capture zooplankton, which plays a major role in the ecosystem. Researchers hope to determine from food web studies if the whales come for the food, or perhaps simply for a summer break.
caption_cleaned: During the Tremblay Ecosystem Approach research season in Nunavut, we’ve been lucky enough to spot bowhead whales. Bowheads can weigh between to tons, reach a length of m, and live up to years; yet, can still manage to launch their massive bodies out of the water! Wow! Bowheads filter water through baleen by straining the surface of the water to capture zooplankton, which plays a major role in the ecosystem. Researchers hope to determine from food web studies if the whales come for the food, or perhaps simply for a summer break.

caption_original: Know much about eelgrass? Eelgrass beds act as nurseries for marine species such as young cod. We recently announced the Coastal Restoration Fund which includes restoring eelgrass beds in Placentia Bay, Newfoundland and Labrador. http://ow.ly/klri30feW97

INUKTITUT
ᓄᓇᕘᒻᒥᐅᑦ! ᑐᓴᒐᒃᓴᒃᑎᐊᕆᒃᑐᒍᑦ ᖃᐅᔨᓴᕐᓂᕆᓚᐅᕐᑕᑦᑎᓐᓂᒃ ᐊᐃᕕᕐᓂᒃ ᑕᕆᐅᖓᓂ Foxe Basin ᐃᓂᖃᕐᑐᑦ. ᐃᓄᓕᒫᕐᑎᑦᑎᓂᐊᕐᑐᒍᑦ ᐃᒡᓗᓕᒃᒥ ᐊᒻᒪᓗ ᓴᓂᕋᔭᒃᒥ ᐅᖃᐅᓯᕆᓗᒋᑦ ᐅᓄᕐᓯᒋᐊᕐᓂᐊᕐᓂᖏᓐᓂᒃ ᐊᐃᕙᒃᑕᐅᔪᓐᓇᕐᑐᑦ ᑐᓴᕋᓱᒃᓗᑕᓗ ᐃᓱᒪᒋᔭᐅᔪᓂᒃ. ᑲᑎᒪᑎᑦᑎᓂᐊᕐᑐᒍᑦ ᐅᑯᓇᓂ: 
- ᐃᒡᓗᓕᒃ ᓯᑎᐱᕆ 26, 2017 ᐃᑲᕋᖓ 7 ᐅᓐᓄᒃᑯᑦ ᐱᙳᐊᕐᕕᖕᒥ 
- ᓴᓂᕋᔭᒃ ᓯᑎᐱᕆ 27, 2017 ᐃᑲᕋᖓ 7 ᐅᓐᓄᒃᑯᑦ ᐱᙳᐊᕐᕕᖕᒥ 
ᐅᐸᒃᓂᐊᕐᐳᑎᑦ ᐃᓱᒪᒋᔭᑎᑦ ᑐᓴᕐᑕᐅᔪᒪᔪᑦ. ᑕᒪᕐᒥᒃ ᐃᓄᐃᑦ ᑐᙵᓱᒃᑎᑕᐅᔪᑦ!

All community members welcome! caption_original: Donning snorkels, masks and fins, DFO biologists routinely plunge into British Columbia’s streams to search for Atlantic salmon. Please report all captures of Atlantic salmon to our toll-free reporting line 1-800-811-6010. These reports help us to determine which streams should be monitored. http://ow.ly/szWM30feVyr
caption_cleaned: Donning snorkels, masks and fins, DFO biologists routinely plunge into British Columbia’s streams to search for Atlantic salmon. Please report all captures of Atlantic salmon to our toll-free reporting line -800-811-6010. These reports help us to determine which streams should be monitored.

caption_original: Our scientists spent a week in the Scotian Shelf examining cold-water sponges, including the glass sponge, Vazella pourtalesi. While there; they also visited our Lophelia Coral Conservation Area to look at the recoverability of the species. Data collected on this trip will be used to develop an integrated approach to help preserve vulnerable deep-sea sponge ecosystems in the North Atlantic. http://ow.ly/8wEE30eZhwm
caption_cleaned: Our scientists spent a week in the Scotian Shelf examining cold-water sponges, including the glass sponge, Vazella pourtalesi. While there; they also visited our Lophelia Coral Conservation Area to look at the recoverability of the species. Data collected on this trip will be used to develop an integrated approach to help preserve vulnerable deep-sea sponge ecosystems in the North Atlantic.

caption_original: Did you know there are four species of Asian carps? Bighead, Black, Grass and Silver carps originated in the major river systems in China and Russia.  These fish are beginning to reach Canadian watersheds and pose major physical, ecological and socio-economic threats. Learn how to report this invasive species here: http://ow.ly/hnR230fprfF

caption_original: The ecosystem research team in Tremblay Sound, Nunavut, came across a bird colony! A glaucous gull colony of approximately 25 couples was found on a cliff at the far south of the strait. These birds can nest in different habitats, like cliffs and wetlands. As a result, they have a broad diet. Remains of fish of different sizes and even lemming bones were found, providing a picture of their diet. The cliff offers gull eggs and young birds protection against predators and excellent access to marine resources.

The cliff offers gull eggs and young birds protection against predators and excellent access to marine resources.

caption_original: Underwater noise and contaminants have become a growing concern for the recovery of the Southern Resident Killer Whale. To help address these threats, the Government of Canada is holding a symposium in Vancouver, October 11-12 to bring together scientists, experts and government officials. For more information visit http://ow.ly/yLs930eZuag

caption_original: Arctic sculpins live in deep and shallow waters where they eat small crustaceans, other small fish and fish larvae. They can tolerate water as cold as -2°C. In order to survive these extreme conditions, they developed a special antifreeze protein to prevent their blood from freezing solid. Sculpins may be a predicator of changes at the bottom of the food web. We collected individuals from two species of sculpins, as part of the ecosystem research project in Tremblay Sound, Nunavut, to better understand their feeding habits, as well as the role they play in the ecosystem.
caption_cleaned: Arctic sculpins live in deep and shallow waters where they eat small crustaceans, other small fish and fish larvae. They can tolerate water as cold as °C. In order to survive these extreme conditions, they developed a special antifreeze protein to prevent their blood from freezing solid. We collected individuals from two species of sculpins, as part of the ecosystem research project in Tremblay Sound, Nunavut, to better understand their feeding habits, as well as the role they play in the ecosystem.

caption_original: Since summer 2016, the Mi’gmaq of Gespeg and Gesgapegiag in Quebec have surveyed the southern shore of the Gaspé Peninsula in search of young striped bass. With help from the Government of Canada's Aboriginal Fund for Species at Risk, they are working to find a second spawning ground in the Southern Gulf of St. Lawrence. There is only one known spawning ground in this area to support the survival of the species, the Miramichi River in New Brunswick. For more details on the project, please visit http://ow.ly/TqFo30fiB0K

caption_original: Every year, our researchers monitor capelin spawning on and near Bellevue Beach in Trinity Bay, NL. In Newfoundland, this forage fish spawns on beaches and near the bottom of the ocean, close to the beaches. Beach spawning is a unique occurrence and is commonly known as the capelin roll. But we rarely get a view of capelin spawning beyond our beaches. Check out this underwater video!

caption_original: The acquisition of two autonomous hydrographic surface vehicles by the Canadian Hydrographic Service could very well be a revolution. This technology makes it possible to design the hydrography of tomorrow... today! Find out what these machines are and how we use them. http://ow.ly/jvjg30f9VqP

caption_original: Hydrographer at the Maurice Lamontagne Institute, Yann Côté-Nadeau participated for ten days in the Canada C3 expedition, a Canada 150 Signature project. During his stay, he introduced the HydroBall technology, which allows inexperienced individuals to assist the Canadian Hydrographic Service in collecting data to design its nautical charts. To learn more about the experience of our scientist aboard the Polar Prince, please visit http://ow.ly/DXoO30fbMoj

caption_original: Have a chat with whale expert Dr. Caroline Fox on board Canada’s C3 mission and DFO’s Philippe Morel, Assistant Deputy Minister of Aquatic Ecosystems, about three of Canada’s endangered whales:  The Southern Resident Killer Whale, the St. Lawrence Estuary Beluga and the North Atlantic Right Whale.  Learn about why these whales are in trouble, the threats they face and what we can do to help.  We know that human activity has an impact and in order to help we need to take action. Get engaged, have a chat with us on Facebook Live and take part in our online engagement that’s happening now at www.letstalkwhales.ca
